http://globalriskinsights.com/2016/05/euroscepticism/ "The EU policy toward Russia and Ukraine is increasing Euroscepticism within national electorates.. . .  "Recent developments highlight the growing rift between western European electorates and the European Union (EU) policy toward Russia, and Ukraine. . . . the implementation of a sanctions regime against Russia and the push for ever closer ties with Kiev . . .  has generated backlashes in national economies and led to the rise of a specific euro-sceptic narrative forged on the opposition between national interests and EU priorities regarding Russia. " . . .  In France, the national economic situation is the key issue driving a wedge between domestic interests and the current EU policy in regard to Russia.  On April 28th, French lawmakers passed a non-binding vote . . . . calling for the end of anti-Russian sanctions. The procedure . . .  was meant to spur the government to engage in a debate concerning the rationality of sanctions on Russia. It followed a call that Economy Minister Emmanuel Macron issued in January 2016 to lift EU sanctions against Russia. Macron’s objective was to end the sanctions regime against Moscow by the summer of 2016 in a bid to restore economic relations between France and Russia and enable the country’s export-oriented sectors to regain access to the lost market. A similar rationale pushed Prime Minister Matteo Renzi to call for a review of EU sanctions against Moscow in late 2015. "The vote built upon a strong opposition by some sectors of the French economy to the EU-wide policy in regards to Moscow. During nationwide protests held between July and September 2015, French farmers demonstrated against their dire economic situation. Protesters criticised the government for a multitude of reasons including heavy regulation and taxation that weigh heavily on their finances. The demonstrators also voiced a clear opposition to France’s participation in the EU sanctions against Russia that led to Moscow’s counter-measures. The latter have been having a major impact on the farmers’ export-driven meat and dairy production. "Within the first five months of 2015, the French agricultural sector lost tens of millions of euros because of the negative backlash of EU sanctions. Anti-sanctions protests held by European farmers took place throughout the EU in summer 2015 as labour unions’ officials claimed that the policy toward Russia cost European farmers approximately EUR 5.5 billion. "On April 6th, the Netherlands held a referendum over the EU Association Agreement with Ukraine. The result of the poll . . . was a clear message of disagreement from a portion of the Dutch electorate in regards to the national government and the EU’s policy over Ukraine, and indirectly Russia. Approximately 60% of those voting expressed their opposition to trade agreements as well as a visa-free policy between the EU and Ukraine. While only over a third of Dutch voted, the result marked a tendency within certain portions of the western European electorate.
. . . 
"As the referendum was non-binding, it is highly likely that the Dutch government will proceed with its EU-oriented policy toward Ukraine. The EU has devoted too much political capital toward the integration of the eastern European country and may push through with its policy regardless. The European Commission already proposed a visa-free travel arrangement to Ukraine.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  The way I read this, although the wider electorate opposes the sanctions, governments have too much invested for the EU to drop them.   However, somebody is going to blink first, and I think it will not be Putin; it will be one of the EU countries.  After somebody lifts their sanction on Russia, I think Putin will begin an immediate review of Russia's counter-sanctions, but I think he'll not hurry to lift them--just to rub it in that we gave in first, and to try to show that Russia isn't hurting.

As reported recently, Putin has said that sanctions imposed by Russia will not be lifted soon. http://www.ibtimes.com/putin-call-show-russian-president-talks-panama-papers-syria-economy-2353671 However, what does "soon" mean? Putin has shown the ability and willingness to make changes quickly. He has the power, and the loyalty behind him, so he can change quickly across multiple scenarios, e.g., removing some Russian support from Syria; recently re-engaging with the West (through Lavrov): http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/04/19/kerry-and-lavrov-the-odd-couple-of-the-new-cold-war.html. Of course the Western sanctions irked the Russians and, thus the tit-for-tat response, but it seems to me a couple bigger forces are the drivers impacting this IFP. (1) Oil prices have stayed low and will probably remain so, thereby causing ongoing and substantial pressures on the Russian economy, budget, balance of payments, etc.; (2) there appears to be a relative stabilization developing across the Crimea area (not solved, and still risky). Interestingly, Russia has seemed to signal a possible way forward between itself and Ukraine that may start to minimize their mutual conflict, e.g, (4/19/16) "Last week Kerry and Lavrov discussed on the phone peace terms for the wars in Ukraine, Syria and Nagorno-Karabakh. Although they disagreed about many major issues, including the conditions for a peace agreement in Ukraine".  Poroshenko hopes Nadezhda Savchenko will be back in Ukraine within weeks. http://tass.ru/en/world/872136 And as an increasing sign of possible movement behind the scenes, there is this from the French Economy Minister: http://www.ndtv.com/world-news/france-hopes-to-see-russia-sanctions-lifted-this-summer-french-economy-minister-1269643 None of this says a big warm and fuzzy is just around the corner, but does indicate shifting landscapes (or calmer waters) behind the scenes. So, am slightly raising my percentage of thinking that between 1-5 food embargo items will be removed before 8/6/16.

COMMENT:  Resolution of this question may hinge on how GJI interprets  an easing, or a lifting of the embargo on only some items (but not all) from a country.  An earlier question about Russia lifting the food embargo was resolved by GJI as "yes" because a nutritional supplement used by elite athletes was lifted--(Tell me, what food group do nutritional supplements fall into?)--a resolution perceived by many as technically correct but not addressing the intent of the question.  The GJI resolution pendulum seems to have swing in the other direction, and that they will resolve this question as "no" unless EVERY item from a country is removed from the embargo:  that is how I have understood their response to my clarification request on this question.

Meanwhile, the disgruntlement of Russian consumers will be held in check by the traditional remedy for economic bans: smuggling. Belarus is now shipping genuine Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese, made only in a few regions in Italy, into Russia with "Made in Belarus" labels slapped over the top of the original Italian labels, for instance. Smuggling will continue apace, because it is lucrative for the smugglers, desirable for the consumers, and a nice income source for suborned customs officials. Russia cannot stop it all; look at cigarettes that come across the US border from Canada for a prime example of the failure of that economic remedy.

From my reading of this question, minor technical changes (like allowing in sports nutrition products) would not count for this question; Russia needs to completely lift the embargo on a country for that country to count.  There are several ways I could see this question resolving:
0: This is the status quo, where Russia keeps the embargo going until its scheduled expiry date (at least).  I think this is by far the most likely option.
1-5: Russia lifts the embargo on one (or maybe a few) peripheral countries (perhaps Greece?).  Seems somewhat unlikely.
>5: This could happen if Russia lifts the embargo on the EU, but not the US.  This seems very unlikely; if Russia is lifting the embargo on most countries, it would be weird to still keep some on the embargo list.
All: Russia lifts the embargo completely.  This is quite possible if Russia and the West reach some sort of accommodation in the next year.  I think this is the second most likely option. I previously gave a 20% estimate that Russia would lift the embargo, or a 80% chance that it wouldn't.  I am lowering that to 70%, and giving most of the rest of the weight to "All".  I am surprised how little weight other forecasters are putting on "All"; if this question resolves on a technicality, it is most likely to resolve in favor of "All", since a lifting of the embargo on certain products would presumably affect all of the countries on the embargo list.
